ç®—æ³•ä¸€å¼€å§‹æ˜¯Dijkstraé™ªè€å©†é€›è¡—è´­ç‰©æ—¶æƒ³å‡ºæ¥çš„ï¼š In 1956, the 26-year-old Dutch computer scientist Edsger Dijkstra wanted to write a program that would show off the capabilities of a brand-new computer called the ARMAC. While shopping with his fiancÃ©e in Amsterdam, he stopped in at a cafÃ© for a break. Thatâ€™s when he hit on the idea for the algorithm (opens a new tab) that now bears his name. He didnâ€™t have writing materials on hand, so over the course of 20 minutes he worked out the details in his head.
